takeaways: A motion requires a second before it can be discussed — this ensures at least two members want to consider the item.
The chair should remain neutral during debate and only votes to break a tie (in most board rules).
A quorum (majority of board members) must be present for any official business to take place.
Motions have a specific order of precedence — privileged motions outrank subsidiary, which outrank main motions.

knowledgeCheck.question: A motion can be discussed immediately after being made, without a second.
knowledgeCheck.explanation: A motion must receive a second before it can be discussed. This ensures at least two members are interested in considering the item.

knowledgeCheck.question: What is a quorum?
options: The board chair plus one member
knowledgeCheck.explanation: A quorum is a majority of the board members. Without a quorum, no official business can be conducted.

knowledgeCheck.question: The board chair should actively debate motions before the board.
knowledgeCheck.explanation: The chair should remain neutral during debate. If the chair wishes to participate in debate, they should temporarily pass the gavel to the vice-chair.
